Award.AwardTitle: Achieving Efficient Spectrum Usage in Active and Passive Sensing Through a Market-Based Approach
Award.AbstractNarration: Opportunities for time-sharing spectrum use could allow for significant improvements in spectrum efficiency. Two large users of spectrum bandwidth -- radar and remote sensing -- are also two applications that might best be able to allow time sharing. For example, radar usually sweeps in direction, which may allow use of the radar frequency in directions not being scanned at any one instant. Remote sensing applications, which often use Dicke switching to switch between the observed source and an internal calibration source, could also allow time sharing during the calibration cycle. The research will investigate the incorporation of a time dimension to spectral allocations, and will also investigate relevant market assessments of the value of spectrum made available through temporal sharing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project's goals have been to develop methods for improving the efficiency of spectrum usage for both active and passive sensor systems. These include both radar (as in air traffic control radar systems) and microwave radiometer systems used for monitoring geophysical properties of the Earth. The development of an economic model for valuing the proposed freed spectrum (which would likely be available on a time-division access basis) was also a key component of the project.

In its early phases, the project investigated spectrum sharing between  icrowave radiometer and communications systems based on a "time division multiple access" (TDMA) strategy. The TDMA method was possible due to the periodic switching of a microwave radiometer to observe internal calibration standards instead of external RF signals. A simple demonstration of spectrum sharing between communications and microwave radiometry users was performed based on this concept.

For radar systems, the team completed a detailed, waveform level simulation to investigate spectrum sharing between a model LTE system and an air traffic control radar system. The team had previously developed a link-budget based analysis of interference, but a simple 'power-only' analysis is not capable of capturing the full impact of interference on radar and communication system performance. These aspects can be captured only by simulating the radar and communication systems waveform as they operate (e.g. with a simulated radar target or a simulated transmitted message to be received.) A simulation environment for performing these analyses was created and used to assess interference issues in sharing between radar and communication users. The results of the study showed that LTE interference appears similar to thermal noise to the radar, so that a link budget computation can be used with SINR replacing SNR in predicting radar performance. The analysis also showed that LTE systems are relatively immune to pulsed radar transmissions, given the adaptive nature of the LTE system that is able to recover from errors on receive. However, the LTE system is more susceptible to radar interference in the early stages of establishing a link. 

The project also conducted modeling studies of "passive radar" systems for future air traffic control. In passive radar, existing transmitters are used to illuminate the area of observation, and the radar does not have a dedicated transmitter. In this fashion, the need for radar spectrum is reduced. A simulation environment to analyze passive radar performance was created and used to assess radar performance metrics in a passive radar mode. Results of the model were compared with measurements from a passive radar system at the OSU ElectroScience Laboratory as a validation of the model's predictions. The favorable agreement achieved validated the model for continued use in passive radar performance modeling for air traffic control. 

Finally, economic analyses of the nature of a market for spectrum sharing were performed. In a network environment with spread spectrum technology, we explored and characterized socially-efficient and revenue-optimal spectrum sharing mechanisms.   Auction implementations of efficient and optimal mechanisms were also proposed. 

Results from the project's studies have been reported in multiple conference and submitted journal publications. The project also supported the doctoral studies of a Ph.D. student at OSU in Electrical and Computer Engineering and a post-doctoral researcher in the Department of Economics.
